item.title: I went to search a car for drugs while on duty. What happened next made me re-evaluate my life
item.description: Police recruitment drives in response to chronic shortages have led to more people applying to join their local force. But what were the factors that led to the shortages in the first place?

item.title: PM Ishiba's resignation plunges Japan into political uncertainty. Here's what happens next
item.description: Since Shigeru Ishiba came to power in October 2024, his ruling coalition has lost its majority in both houses of parliament.

item.title: Massive drone attack on Kyiv sees Government buildings hit for the first time
item.description: Russia’s heaviest drone and missile barrage since the war began has struck Kyiv’s Cabinet of Ministers building, leaving four dead, including an infant. Ukraine is now calling for greater global support and tougher sanctions on Russia, targeting its economy.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 8th September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'Not serious about ceasefire': What Russia's major attack means for the war in Ukraine
item.description: The strike on Kyiv is less about causing damage, but more a signal from Russian President Vladimir Putin towards the West, an expert says.

item.title: K-pop is a global phenomenon. Some of its biggest stars are from Australia
item.description: From BLACKPINK's Rosé to Stray Kids' Bang Chan and Felix, Australia is slowly making its presence in Korean pop music felt.

item.title: Fed up with flight delays? Passengers could soon get refunds under new scheme
item.description: The federal government aims to implement a new consumer protection scheme for travellers, which could lead to refunds and the establishment of a new complaints-handling body to address flight disruptions.

item.title: Weak US data spurs rate cut chance, and the supermarkets court case
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Raymond Chan from Morgans about the day's sharemarket action including the weak US jobs data, a rebalancing of the market's main indexes and the potential implications of a supermarkets underpayments court case.

item.title: The new regional hotspot that's seen a 1,500 per cent surge of city folk
item.description: More city dwellers are packing their bags and heading for this regional border location, according to the latest Regional Movers Index.

item.title: Logging halted to create a koala retreat
item.description: Australia will halt logging in a large stretch of woodland on the east coast to create a retreat for koalas, in an attempt to save the local population from extinction. The announcement, which will impact six timber mills and hundreds of workers, has caused outrage in the forestry industry. New South Wales Premier Chris Minns says the decision wasn't taken lightly and those affected will be supported.

item.title: Banksy mural at Royal Courts of Justice swiftly covered after appearing overnight
item.description: The new Banksy mural appeared to be a commentary on the arrest of hundreds of demonstrators in London for their support of proscribed terrorist organisation Palestine Action.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 9 September 2025
item.description: A Five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: ANZ slashes 3,500 jobs, are there more to come?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a closer look at ANZ's decision to cut 3,500 employees and 1,000 contractors and what it means for the sector with Nathan Zaia from Morningstar and Damien Boey from Wilson Asset Management.

item.title: Gaza aid flotilla reports second attack after Tunisian authorities say 'no drones' involved in first
item.description: The vessel was off the coast of Tunisia when it was struck by a drone, organisers of the Global Sumud Flotilla allege. Tunisian authorities have rejected the claim, saying the explosion originated inside the boat.

item.title: Gaza aid flotilla reports second attack after Tunisian authorities say 'no drones' involved in first
item.description: The vessel was off the coast of Tunisia when it was struck by a drone, organisers of the Global Sumud Flotilla allege. Tunisian authorities have rejected the claim, saying the explosion originated inside the boat.

item.title: Palestinians flee Gaza City as Israel airdrops leaflets ordering them to leave
item.description: Israel has warned it will launch a full-scale assault on Gaza City.

item.title: The simple shopping swap that could save you $4,000 a year
item.description: A comparison group examined the cost of 20 staple items at two major supermarkets. Here's what it found.

item.title: Qatar condemns Israeli attacks on Hamas leaders as 'cowardly' violation of international law
item.description: Israel's airstrike on Hamas leaders in Qatar killed five, including a commander's son, prompting Qatari condemnation and US unease over ceasefire efforts.

item.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise
item.description: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

item.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise
item.description: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

item.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise
item.description: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

item.title: 'The wrong thing to do': Australia, and the world, react to Israel’s strike on Hamas in Qatar
item.description: Qatar has once again been caught in the crossfire of Middle East turmoil, with world leaders condemning the attacks amid concerns they deal a serious blow to ceasefire efforts.

item.title: Will Israel's attack on Hamas officials in Qatar derail peace talks?
item.description: Israel has struck the Qatari capital of Doha, killing five Hamas members and one Qatari security official. It has led to an outcry from Qatar, Washington, and humanitarian groups, with concern the strike will jeopardise fragile ceasefire talks.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 10 September 2025
item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Upcoming far-right and far-left protests on a violent collision course, police warn
item.description: People are sick of protesters using rallies as a "veiled excuse to punch on", a Victorian Police spokesperson has said, warning of a rival protests planned for Melbourne this Saturday.

item.title: 'Absolutely reckless': NATO condemns Russia's violation of Polish airspace
item.description: Poland invoked NATO's Article 4 for urgent talks after Russian drones violated the country's airspace.

item.title: Israel's strike in Qatar a 'devastating blow' to Gaza ceasefire negotiations, experts say
item.description: Israel has carried out airstrikes and other military action in Lebanon, Syria, Iran and Yemen in the course of the Gaza conflict, but experts say its latest attack on Qatar marks a significant departure and "upsets" efforts for peace.

item.title: Breakthrough chlamydia vaccine offers hope for endangered koalas
item.description: A world-first vaccine for chlamydia in koala populations developed over more than a decade may help the fight against the disease.

item.title: Climate Change and China's Charm: Australia's pressing role to play in the Pacific
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is in the Solomon Islands for the region's most important annual political meeting. With climate change and regional security at the forefront of discussions, Australia will work to solidify its role as a reliable partner and counter to China's growing security presence in the Pacific.

item.title: How much you need for a comfortable retirement? | NAB latest to cut jobs
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Marcus Bogdan from Blackmore Capital about the day's market action including why banks seem to be on a job cutting cycle, plus Stephnie Youssef speaks with ASFA CEO Mary Delahunty to find out how much money is needed in super to fund a comfortable retirement.

item.title: 'Incredibly rare': The million-dollar question on Dezi Freeman's arrest reward
item.description: There's $1 million available for anyone who can help facilitate the arrest of accused double murderer Dezi Freeman. But do financial incentives actually help solve crimes?

item.title: Trump 'filled with grief' over Charlie Kirk's shooting. Here's what to know about the right-wing activist
item.description: The shooting prompted condemnation of political violence and calls for unity from US leaders across the political spectrum.

item.title: Qatar says 'regional response under way' after Israeli strike on Doha
item.description: Gulf leaders have rallied in solidarity with Qatar as global condemnation over the strikes grows.

item.title: 'Girt by sea' explained: National anthem now in 60+ languages
item.description: Ever wondered what "girt by sea" means, especially if your first language isn't English? SBS Audio has brought Australia’s national anthem to life in more than 60 languages, so everyone can understand the words behind the music.

item.title: Bali floods leave at least 19 people dead and five missing
item.description: Floodwaters rose to over 2.5 metres in some areas, with more than 800 people forced into temporary shelters.

item.title: Bali floods leave at least 19 people dead and five missing
item.description: Floodwaters rose to over 2.5 metres in some areas, with more than 800 people forced into temporary shelters.

item.title: Bali floods leave at least 19 people dead and five missing
item.description: Floodwaters rose to over 2.5 metres in some areas, with more than 800 people forced into temporary shelters.

item.title: Bali floods leave at least 19 people dead and five missing
item.description: Floodwaters rose to over 2.5 metres in some areas, with more than 800 people forced into temporary shelters.

item.title: Ley apologises to Indian Australians, says Price remains 'valued' party member after sacking
item.description: Sussan Ley's apology come after she dumped Jacinta Nampijinpa Price from the Opposition frontbench over the senator's remarks about Indian migrants and her refusal to endorse her leadership.

item.title: Europe on high alert after Russian drones shot down over Poland
item.description: Poland has reported its most serious airspace breach since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, after nearly 20 drones entered from Belarus and Ukraine. European leaders have condemned Moscow for reckless escalation, with the Kremlin saying such accusations are baseless.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 11 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: 'I won't be silenced': Jacinta Price axed from Coalition frontbench in fallout over Indian migration remarks
item.description: Northern Territory Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has been removed from the Coalition frontbench, following fallout from remarks she made about Indian migrants. Sydney Lang takes a look at how the last week unfolded.

item.title: Israel strikes Qatar, why it's been a bad week to be a PM & the real 'Succession' finale
item.description: Israel's strike on Qatar blows up ceasefire talks, the prime ministers of Nepal, Japan and France depart in a hurry, and Albanese battles for influence in the Pacific, while Moldova battles to stop Putin’s influence ahead of elections. Plus, the Murdoch succession is finally settled.

item.title: What you might not know about tornadoes in Australia
item.description: There are about 60-80 tornadoes each year in Australia, according to a meteorologist. But you're unlikely to see them.

item.title: US stocks benefit from Oracle surge; home ownership dream slipping
item.description: The ASX 200 has closed 0.3% lower with healthcare stocks dragging the index down, despite gains by gold miners. That’s almost despite Oracle’s shares soaring almost 40% in its best one-day performance since 1992, lifting the S&P 500 and other global markets to record highs. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets. Plus, new analysis from Domain shows the dream of owning a home is becoming further out of reach – with deposit hurdles, coupled with climbing house prices and mortgage repayments, driving the sharpest generational divide in decades. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Domain’s research chief, Dr Nicola Powell.

item.title: Sydney sets 146-year rainfall record as severe weather eases
item.description: Over the 24 hours to 9am on Thursday, Sydney received a total of 122mm of rain, marking its heaviest daily rainfall for September since 1879.

item.title: Julie Bishop hits back at bullying claims and vows to stay at ANU after deputy quits
item.description: ANU chancellor Julie Bishop has rejected bullying allegations, and has vowed to serve out her term after vice-chancellor Genevieve Bell quit following months of controversy.

item.title: 'People starting to act out': How the Charlie Kirk shooting suggests a 'vicious spiral' in the US
item.description: Is the US seeing a rise in political violence, and could it spread to Australia?

item.title: More than a million Australians could be living with dementia in 40 years. These are possible risk factors
item.description: A new report has also found dementia was Australia's leading cause of death in 2023.

item.title: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years in jail for plotting coup
item.description: The firebrand ex-president was convicted of plotting a coup after his 2022 election loss, and accused of acting "with the purpose of eroding democracy and institutions".

item.title: 'Doesn't cut the mustard': Indian Australian community leaders demand Price apology
item.description: While welcoming an apology from Opposition leader Sussan Ley, one Indian Australian community figure said "the Liberal Party has their work cut out to repair the damage" caused by senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's comments on Indian immigration.

item.title: Ireland says it will boycott Eurovision 2026 if Israel is allowed to participate
item.description: Irish broadcaster RTE said it would be "unconscionable" to take part in the contest alongside Israel, given its ongoing assault on Gaza.

item.title: Brazil's former President Bolsonaro sentenced to jail
item.description: Brazil's former President, Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to prison after being convicted of plotting a coup to remain in power after losing the 2022 election. Mr Bolsonaro, who has denied any wrongdoing, has not attended the court and has only sent his lawyers.He is the first former president in the country's history to be convicted for attacking democracy.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 12 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: A 5-minute guide to the World Athletics Championships – and how to watch from Australia
item.description: Australia has kicked off one of its biggest track and field campaigns in history, with a record number of athletes in Tokyo to contest the 2025 World Athletics Championships.

item.title: Why the final approval for North West Shelf gas plant has Indigenous groups and environmentalists worried
item.description: The federal government has given the final approval for the Woodside North West Shelf gas project with a series of conditions. The approval comes ahead of the Albanese government's announcement of a 2035 emissions reduction target, and after Australia emphasised its commitment to tackling climate change to Pacific leaders.

item.title: Former Virgin CEO’s $50m payday; & is a US rate cut locked in?
item.description: Former Virgin Australia CEO Jayne Hrdlicka is collecting a $49.9 million pay packet, which includes 10 million shares, as revealed in the company’s annual report. For more on this and the ASX-200’s performance this week, Stephanie Youssef spoke with IG Markets analyst Tony Sycamore. Plus, US inflation has risen 2.9% in August, paving the way for the first US interest rate cut of the year when the Federal Reserve meets next week. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with AMP Chief Economist Shane Oliver.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Envoy Aftab Malik on 'going to the roots' of Islamophobia in Australia
item.description: The Special Envoy to Combat Islamophobia has handed down his long-awaited report, containing 54 recommendations to the federal government.

item.title: $548.5 million: The price the government is willing to pay 'to avoid a public trial' of robodebt
item.description: The robodebt class action settlement has been billed as the largest of its kind in Australian history. However, one expert argues it represents "accountability avoided", leaving questions of misfeasance unanswered.

item.title: Bruce McAvaney on Australia's emerging athletics 'golden age' and the run that inspired us all
item.description: Australia's "golden age" in athletics is gathering steam, esteemed sports commentator Bruce McAvaney says, as the World Athletics Championships gets underway.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Three years after the death of Mahsa Amini in Iran, what's changed?
item.description: Dr Dara Conduit at the University of Melbourne explains the impact of the death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini three years ago on women's rights in Iran today.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Supermarket sweep: How making wise choices could save you money
item.description: Making the switch from branded products to a store's home brand alternatives could save shoppers thousands of dollars each year at checkout, according to a financial comparison website. SBS's Cameron Carr has been finding out more from Compare the Market spokesman Phillip Portman.

item.title: 'More political in recent years': Fresh details emerge about suspected Charlie Kirk shooter
item.description: Tyler Robinson expressed dislike for Charlie Kirk in the lead-up to the conservative commentator's assassination, investigators have been told.

item.title: PM's wardrobe malfunction and SUV diplomacy: What you missed from the Pacific summit
item.description: Australia's fossil fuel exports remain a source of tension as Pacific leaders double down on their support for a bid to co-host global climate talks.

item.title: 'Paradigm shift': Over 2 million homes to get internet speed boost starting this weekend
item.description: The free speed boost is one of the biggest changes to Australian internet in history, according to one expert.

item.title: Protesters clash in Melbourne as rival rallies unfold across the country
item.description: Opposing protests took place across all capital cities and some regional areas on Saturday and, as police had predicted, things got most heated in Melbourne

item.title: Concerns over political extremism after rival rallies held across Australia
item.description: Politicians are warning against the risks of extremism and political violence, after rival rallies were held in Australia's capital cities and regional centres.

item.title: Nick was a 'subservient' child in church, but 'tiny little cracks' eventually shattered his faith
item.description: It took an "unravelling" for musician Nick Carpenter to be able to reckon with his religious upbringing in America's south and find his voice in songwriting. But he still thinks about the person he could have been.

item.title: 'I'm ready to be arrested': How women in Iran fight 'state-sanctioned sexual violence'
item.description: Three years after the death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini, which sparked the widespread "Woman, Life, Freedom" movement, women are still finding ways to protest against the regime's new methods of crackdown.

item.title: What next for the Coalition after its 'entirely unedifying week'?
item.description: Liberal senator Jane Hume says the Coalition is looking to "move on" after demoting colleague Jacinta Nampijinpa Price over controversial comments about Indian immigration. But what are the lessons the Coalition should draw from the episode?

item.title: Loo scrolling: Study investigates link between this bathroom habit and a painful health condition
item.description: Using your phone while on the toilet could be linked to an increased chance of haemorrhoids, according to a study from the United States. So if you're a loo scroller, the extra time spent on the toilet could be doing you more harm than good.

item.title: INTERVIEW: The new Aged Care Act and the 'unintended consequences' preventing transformational change
item.description: A new Aged Care Act is weeks away from coming into effect, but there are aspects that has the Inspector-General of Aged Care concerned.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Is there life on Mars? New research seems to show there was, once.
item.description: This week, NASA announced findings of potential biosignatures on Mars. Does that mean there's proof that there was once life on Mars? In this edition of Weekend One on One, Dr Micheal Tice, geology professor at Texas A&M University, who's involved in the ongoing research project, explains what the findings mean.

item.title: Government to spend $12 billion on 'world-class' AUKUS defence facility in WA
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a $12 billion investment into a Western Australian defence precinct, which is set to bolster Australia's ability to build warships and host nuclear-powered submarines.

item.title: This common bathroom habit could be doing you more damage than you think
item.description: Using your phone on the throne could lead to an increased risk of haemorrhoids, according to a new study, but some experts say it's not the full story.

item.title: Rubio reiterates unwavering US support for Israel as dozens killed in Gaza City offensive
item.description: The US secretary of state said Israel's recent airstrike in Qatar was "not going to change the nature of our relationship with the Israelis" but the two nations were "going to have to talk about" its impact on Gaza ceasefire negotiations.

item.title: Cali lives a proud 'trad life'. But a former tradwife says the lifestyle left her 'dead inside'
item.description: 'Tradwife' influencers like Cali believe a woman’s most important roles are as a wife and a mother — and they also believe in sharing that lifestyle to their online followers. But a former tradwife says the growing popularity of this content is extremely concerning.

item.title: Qatari prime minister says 'time has come to punish Israel' after unprecedented strike on Doha
item.description: Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani has called on the world to reject what he called "double standards" after an Israeli strike on Doha, as Arab and Islamic leaders attend an emergency summit.

item.title: Albanese says Australia-PNG defence treaty on par with US and New Zealand
item.description: More detail will be provided once the defence agreement is signed on Wednesday, the prime minister said.

item.title: Albanese says Australia-PNG defence treaty on par with US and New Zealand
item.description: More detail will be provided once the defence agreement is signed on Wednesday, the prime minister said.

item.title: Iranian women find new ways to resist three years on from Mahsa Amini's death
item.description: In Iran, mandatory hijab laws sparked nationwide protests three years ago over death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini. While the presence of morality police on the streets has declined, the regime says it is instead using digital tools such as citizen-watch apps, drones and facial recognition to enforce its crackdown. But women are finding new ways to resist.

item.title: 'A real slap in the face': ANZ to be handed record fine for misconduct
item.description: The penalties the financial watchdog and ANZ will request include a record $80 million fine for unconscionable conduct.

item.title: No Australians immune: What 2050 and beyond will look like for your city
item.description: Australia is likely to experience more intense and extreme climate hazards — in some cases where people and places haven't experienced them before.

item.title: Arab leaders urge international community to stop applying 'double standards' to Israel
item.description: An Israeli strike on Doha last week has set off a wave of condemnation, with Arab and Islamic leaders gathering in Qatar to arrive at a united response. Israel, meanwhile, is standing firm, deepening its alliance with Washington as the war in Gaza rages on.

item.title: Urgent calls for the federal government to adopt recommendations to combat Islamophobia
item.description: Prominent calls are being made for the federal government to adopt newly-introduced recommendations, following a report by the government-appointed Envoy to Combat Islamophobia. It follows data from the Islamophobia Register Australia, revealing a 530 per cent increase in incidents since October 7, 2023.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 15th September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Adolescence star Owen Cooper becomes youngest male actor to win an Emmy
item.description: The four-part series he starred in recorded 140 million views in its first three months on Netflix, and drew rave reviews.

item.title: 'No Australian spared': National Climate Risk Assessment delivers dire warning
item.description: Coastal hazards driven by climate change could put three million people at risk by 2090 if Australia warms by 3 degrees, according to a major body of new climate research released by the federal government. The National Climate Risk Assessment has been released, as the government prepares the ground to announce its carbon emissions reduction target for 2035.

item.title: ANZ cops $240m fine for widespread misconduct
item.description: The Australian share market has begun the week lower, despite optimism ahead of the US Federal Reserve’s expected interest rate cut this week. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Macquarie Private Bank Division Director Martin Lakos. Plus, ANZ has been fined $240 million for what ASIC has called widespread misconduct, including allegations of failing to respond to customer hardship notices and failing to refund fees charged to thousands of dead customers. For more, Asha Abdi spoke with Professor Allan Fels from the University of Melbourne.

item.title: How much money do you really need to be happy? Here's what the research says
item.description: Recent data shows that economic inequality in Australia is increasing.

item.title: Inside the 'hyper-connected' nationalist groups fuelling protests in Australia and the UK
item.description: There is a complex picture behind the recent mobilisation of the far-right across Australia and the UK. But experts say it's happened before.

item.title: Israel threatens Hamas 'wherever they are' as Arab leaders review ties after Qatar attack
item.description: Arab and Muslim leaders called for a review of ties with Israel after emergency talks in Doha following last week's strike in the Qatari capital.

item.title: Kurtis Marschall takes pole vault bronze for Australia at World Athletics Championships 2025
item.description: Pole vaulter Kurtis Marschall has won Australia's first medal of the Tokyo world championships and Mondo Duplantis has broken his own world record in the event.

item.title: Gout Gout is through to his World Athletics Championships semi-final. Here's how to watch
item.description: The Australian sprinting sensation is making his senior international debut in Tokyo. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Liberal senator warns of 'mass exodus' from Coalition frontbench over net zero
item.description: The Liberal party is once again at loggerheads over the party's stance on net zero, with another frontbencher warning against adopting a policy "at any cost".

item.title: 'Israel is fighting a war of slavery': Strong criticism from emergency summit in Qatar
item.description: Arab and Islamic leaders have met in Doha following Israel’s strike that killed Hamas officials and a Qatari security officer. Qatar’s Emir accused Israel of seeking dominance, while Iran, Turkey and Egypt called for sanctions, isolation and regional defence coordination.

item.title: What social media platforms will — and won't — have to do under Australia's under-16s ban
item.description: Australia's eSafety commissioner has unveiled guidelines for social media companies to comply with age restriction laws that will come into effect on 10 December. Here's what we know.

item.title: Doctor 'furious' after being told to leave Virgin Australia lounge for expressing breast milk
item.description: Virgin Australia has apologised, saying the way the matter was handled "fell short" of its standards.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 16 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Cash-for-votes, deepfakes and propaganda: Russia's latest bid for influence
item.description: As Russia's neighbour prepares to head to the polls, a pro-Russian alliance appears to be on the rise thanks, in part, to a disinformation and propaganda campaign some believe is backed by the Kremlin.

item.title: Australian dollar hits a 10 month high against the US
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a look at the driving forces in the currency markets with Chris Weston from Pepperstone and previews the US Federal Reserve's Thursday morning interest rate decision.

item.title: Israel has committed genocide against Palestinians in Gaza, UN inquiry finds
item.description: The UN commission of inquiry concluded that Israeli authorities and forces had, since October 2023, committed "four of the five genocidal acts" listed in the 1948 Genocide Convention.

item.title: Deep rifts widen further within Coalition under climate change pressure
item.description: Liberal senator Jonathan Duniam has warned the Coalition will face a "mass exodus" from its frontbench if it adopts a net zero policy without caveats, handing Opposition leader Sussan Ley a fresh test over the party's stance on climate action. The warning comes a day after Liberal MP Andrew Hastie threatened to quit the party if it pursued a policy of net zero emissions by 2050.

item.title: 'As data-minimising as possible': under-16 social media ban guidelines published
item.description: Australia's eSafety commissioner has published regulatory guidelines for social media platforms, giving effect to the government's under-16 social media ban. While the ban won't be in place until December 10th, the eSafety commissioner says they want it to be as minimally invasive as possible. Under the guidance, social media platforms will not have to verify the age of every user on their platforms.

item.title: 'Carnage': Israel launches major ground offensive in Gaza
item.description: The ground incursion into Gaza City comes as a UN independent commission concluded in a report that Israel has committed genocide in Gaza.

item.title: Cocaine, cartels, and questions: Concerns over Trump's drug boat 'hunt'
item.description: The US has carried out deadly strikes on Venezuelan boats it alleges carried 'narcoterrorists'. But are these killings lawful? And why is the US turning its focus to the South American nation?

item.title: Modified and dangerous: The popular 'illegal motorbikes' on Australia's roads
item.description: Modified e-bikes that can run well over their legal speed limit are causing serious injuries and even deaths — is it time for Australia to crack down?

item.title: When Andrea’s husband died, their blended family was 'instantaneously decimated'
item.description: Maintaining contact with step or blended family after a separation can be difficult and give rise to mixed emotions — especially when there are no legal responsibilities between stepparents and stepchildren.

item.title: 'I had enough of his hatred': Texts reveal motive as charges filed in Charlie Kirk murder
item.description: Utah prosecutors have charged 22-year-old Tyler Robinson with the murder of right-wing activist Charlie Kirk, announcing plans to seek the death penalty.

item.title: Chalmers reacts to Trump's rebuke as ABC journalist says president was 'feisty'
item.description: The ABC's Americas editor John Lyons joked he would have to "brace himself" after US President Donald Trump said he was going to tell Prime Minister Anthony Albanese about him.

item.title: Australia-PNG defence pact on hold, but PM insists it'll still be inked
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was expected to sign the landmark defence treaty while visiting Papua New Guinea.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 17 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Four arrested after Epstein, Trump images projected on castle ahead of president's visit
item.description: Four adults were arrested on suspicion of malicious communications after protesters unfurled a massive banner featuring a photograph of Trump and Epstein near Windsor Castle, and later projected several images of the pair onto one of its towers.

item.title: Charlie Kirk's alleged killer has been charged. Trump's base has its sights on a different target
item.description: Fears are growing of a looming crackdown on Donald Trump's perceived political opponents after the US president and members of his administration warned the "radical left" would face consequences for the assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk.

item.title: UN commission says Israel committed genocide; thousands flee Israeli assault on Gaza City
item.description: Israel has intensified its ground assault on Gaza City just hours after a UN committee released a report adding to widespread accusations of genocide. The Australian government is among a growing chorus of countries - and hostage families - calling for Israel to change course.

item.title: No deal: Albanese leaves empty-handed after PNG delays defence pact
item.description: The Prime Minister is leaving Papua New Guinea empty-handed after a landmark security agreement wasn't signed in the final hours. The delayed deal comes less than two weeks after a similar defence with Vanuatu was delayed over concerns it will affect their other relationships.

item.title: Charlie Kirk killing suspect could face death penalty after being formally charged with murder
item.description: The 22-year-old suspected of killing conservative activist Charlie Kirk has been formally charged with capital murder. Meanwhile, the fallout from the assassination continues to reverberate across the United States, in the courts, in politics, and in public debate.

item.title: The bank of mum and dad helping first home buyers, & investors look to US Federal Reserve
item.description: Parents and grandparents are increasingly offering financial assistance to family members with 20 per cent saying they provided help in the last quarter, so SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with UBS Economist Stephen Wu to find out to what extent they're helping. Plus Kyle Rodda from capital.com looks through the day's sharemarket action and previews the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

item.title: Australia's newest citizens welcomed in ceremonies on Australian Citizenship Day
item.description: Thousands are celebrating becoming new Australians, as local councils hosted ceremonies around the country for Australian Citizenship Day. SBS spoke to some of the new citizens.

item.title: Israel opens 'temporary' new route out of Gaza City for 48 hours as tanks advance
item.description: An Israeli official said military operations were focused on getting civilians to head south and that fighting would intensify over the next month or two.

item.title: Gout Gout soars into semifinal 'against the big dogs' at World Athletics Championships
item.description: Sprint sensation Gout Gout has lived up to the hype by qualifying for the 200m semi-finals at the world championships.

item.title: I grew up in several blended families. Olivia was the only stable maternal figure in my life
item.description: Actor and singer Tottie Goldsmith didn’t have much contact with her mother growing up and was raised in blended families as her dad remarried several times. She says that she craved emotional stability and connection during this time and so found a consistent maternal figure in her late aunt, Olivia Newton-John.

item.title: The key question for Australia after UN report's Gaza genocide finding
item.description: The UN Independent International Commission of Inquiry report found Israel is committing genocide in Gaza — an accusation it denies. Experts say the recommendations provide a blueprint for the Australian government to take stronger action, but will it?

item.title: Pomp, protests and an 'eternal' bond on day one of Donald Trump's UK state visit
item.description: The visit, marked by record security, protests and awkward questions over Jeffrey Epstein, is being used by UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer to push trade talks and secure major US tech investments.

item.title: The transnational links between extremist groups fuelling protests in Australia and the UK
item.description: Experts say there are a number of driving forces behind recent mass demonstrations in Australia and the UK, and says they are "not particularly exceptional". They also say media organisations need to treat this issue with caution when reporting.

item.title: Albanese unveils 2035 emissions reduction target — and billions in new funding
item.description: The federal government has unveiled a target to cut emissions by 62 to 70 per cent.

item.title: Calls for change to Low Income Super Tax Offset rule
Jimmy Kimmel Live taken off air indefinitely after host's Charlie Kirk comments
item.description: Kimmel suggested during his show this week that Donald Trump's base had used the death of right-wing commentator Kirk for political gain.

item.title: Unlawful: Kmart's facial recognition tech breached Australians' privacy, watchdog finds
item.description: Kmart broke Australian privacy laws through its use of facial recognition technology, the privacy commissioner has found. The retail giant said it was "disappointed" by the findings and was reviewing appeal options.

item.title: Ben and Jerry's co-founder quits over parent company Unilever 'silencing' activism
item.description: Jerry Greenfield said the independence of the company to pursue social activism on progressive issues — a key element in its sale to the British multinational in 2000 — was "gone".

item.title: Palestinians fleeing Gaza City as Israel opens additional exit passage
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Gazans are fleeing south as Israel’s bombardment of the enclave intensifies, with families forced to carry children and the elderly along designated so-called safe routes.Meanwhile, Israel’s far-right finance minister has controversially described Gaza as a potential real estate bonanza once demolished.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 18 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Mixed reactions to Australia's 2035 emissions target | Evening News Bulletin 18 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, the government hands down its net zero climate target for 2025, veteran broadcaster Alan Jones pleads not guilty to dozens of sexual abuse charges. And in sport, US Olympic sprinter Fred Kerley is the first track athlete to sign on to the Enhanced Games.

item.title: 'Not likely to please anyone': Labor's 'ambitious' new emissions target faces criticism
item.description: The updated target has been criticised as both insufficient and overly ambitious.

item.title: 'One of the highest honours of my life': Donald Trump hails UK state visit amid protests
item.description: United States President Donald Trump is visiting the United Kingdom where he has met with members of the Royal family and talked up the historical bond between the two countries.

item.title: Too high or too low? Australia's 2035 climate target pleases no one
item.description: As one of the world's biggest greenhouse gas emitters per capita, Australia has announced its new 2035 emissions reduction target. The federal government has committed to a target to cut emissions by 62 to 70 per cent by 2035, based on 2005 levels. Some say the target is too high, others say it's too low. Labor says it's both ambitious and achievable.

item.title: Full-time jobs tumble, US cuts rates & future of chocolate prices
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Blair Chapman from Seek about the latest jobs data which showed a near 41,000 fall in full-time jobs; Lochlan Halloway from Morningstar takes a look at the day's sharemarket action including the reaction to the US Federal Reserve's first interst rate cut this year; and Stephanie Youssef discusses the future of chocolate prices with Paul Joules from Rabobank.

item.title: Regulator says Kmart's use of facial recognition technology breached privacy laws
item.description: Retail giant Kmart has been accused of violating customers' privacy with its use of facial recognition. The company says it trialled the technology to tackle increased theft and fraud and is considering appealing the Privacy Commissioner's ruling.

item.title: The $500 million problem caused by an 'out-of-date' super rule
item.description: One part of Australia's superannuation system has been "frozen for years" — and its a problem that could be leaving some shortchanged, according to a new report.

item.title: Trump's royal treatment, UN declares 'genocide' in Gaza & Albania's AI minister
item.description: Donald Trump gets some face time with the King & Queen on a state visit to the UK. A UN commission of inquiry finds Israel’s war in Gaza amounts to genocide as Israel’s ground operation in Gaza City gets underway. MAGA vows war on the left in response to Charlie Kirk's killing and Bolsonaro is sentenced to 27 years in jail. Plus, Albania unveils an all AI minister.

item.title: Foreign policy, free speech and Epstein: Takeaways from Trump and Starmer's press conference
item.description: The US and UK leaders hailed the renewal of the countries' "special relationship" as Trump's state visit drew to a close.

item.title: Gout Gout is out of the World Athletics Championships — but time is on his side
item.description: The 17-year-old placed fourth in the second semi-final on Thursday night with a time of 20.36 seconds.

item.title: Ned's grandson died in police custody. Three months on, the cause still isn't confirmed.
item.description: The police-led investigation into Kumanjayi White's death in custody is still ongoing, amid growing frustration and anger from the Yuendumu community.

item.title: The Aussie dollar is having a moment. Here's what it means for you
item.description: The Australian dollar is trading at around a 10-month high against the US dollar and has been broadly performing "very well". But it's not the whole story, experts say.

item.title: Two killed in a shooting at the Israel Jordan border | Morning News Bulletin 19 September 2025
item.description: Two killed in a shooting at the Israel Jordan border; Fears for a pilot after a suspected plane crash on the New South Wales south coast; And in sport, Gout Gout and Torrie Lewis both out of the world titles in Tokyo.

item.title: Sydney's army of Olympic volunteers mark 25 years
item.description: This week marks 25 years since the opening of the Sydney Olympics. From welcoming athletes to washing t-shirts, an army of than 46,000 volunteers helped maintain the smooth running of the games - including pioneer volunteers who volunteered in the years leading up to the games.

item.title: Police arrest seven teenagers over stabbing deaths of Melbourne boys
item.description: Seven males between the ages of 15 and 19 will be interviewed by Victoria Police detectives in connection with the stabbings earlier this month.

item.title: Trump and Starmer keep it civil despite disagreements
item.description: Donald Trump says Vladimir Putin has “let him down”, and revealed the US is working to regain control of a key air base in Afghanistan, during a wide-ranging press conference that marked the end of his state visit to the United Kingdom. British Prime Minister Keir Starmer farewelled his guest - relieved the trip went without any major controversy.

item.title: Trump's new warning to TV networks as criticism over Kimmel suspension mounts
item.description: The head of the US' broadcasting regulator said the cancellation was part of a "massive shift" taking place in US media and that Jimmy Kimmel's show wouldn't be "the last shoe to drop".

item.title: Why landmark coercive control laws have only led to a handful of charges
item.description: NSW Police recorded 297 incidents of coercive control in the year since it was criminalised in the state, but laid charges only on nine occasions.

item.title: Telecommunications blackout, power being restored in Gaza | Midday News Bulletin 19 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, a telecommunications blackout as Israel's army advances on Gaza City, Donald Trump reveals he is negotiating to take back a strategic airbase in Afghanistan. And in sport, sprinting prodigy, Gout Gout, promises a comeback after elimination from the World Athletics Championships.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 19 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: What we know about Charlie Kirk's memorial service
item.description: Charlie Kirk, a right-wing political commentator, was assassinated while speaking at a university campus in the US state of Utah last week.

item.title: Coalition raises concerns over climate goal cost | Evening News Bulletin 19 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, the Coalition reveals concerns over the cost of the government's new emissions target, ANU chancellor Julie Bishop defies pressure to resign, defending herself against bullying claims. And in cricket, Australian captain Pat Cummins shares his plan to recover in time for the Ashes.

item.title: Why we're retiring five years later — and the 'big problem' for future generations
item.description: A "significant shift" has pushed back the age Australians are retiring, according to an author of a new report.

item.title: 'Right plan for Australia': Government ministers defend 2035 climate target
item.description: Climate advocates say the federal government's 2035 emissions reduction target falls "dangerously short", while the Coalition has said its plan is "grounded in fantasy land". Government ministers are now working to justify the target to the public and the community, as the Coalition is under pressure to outline their climate policy.

item.title: Age pension to rise & is AI in bubble territory?
item.description: Stephanie Youssef speaks with Omkar Joshi from Opal Capital Management for the day's sharemarket news, including whether AI is in bubble territory, while SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves goes through the upcoming age pension changes with Joshua Parisotto from HESTA.

item.title: Israelis shot at Allenby Crossing into Jordan
item.description: The Israeli military has confirmed four of its personnel were killed in Rafah as well as two Israeli citizens, in a shooting described as a terrorist attack at Allenby Crossing. The crisis has deepened divisions around the world and at the United Nations, where a US veto blocked a resolution calling for a ceasefire and unrestricted aid.

item.title: Three people dead after Optus network upgrade sparked triple-zero call failure
item.description: Two of the deceased were from South Australia and one from Western Australia, Optus CEO Stephen Rue said.

item.title: Optus’ triple-zero outage is unacceptable, says minister | Morning News Bulletin 20 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Optus's technical outage causing a triple-0 failure is unacceptable, minister says; A British couple detained by the Taliban in Afghanistan for nearly eight months is released; and in AFL, Geelong beats Hawthorn into the Grand Final but loses star defender Tom Stewart to concussion.

item.title: 'Really angry': Isabel is one of hundreds considering class action against this IVF provider
item.description: Hundreds of Australians have shown interest in a class action lawsuit, which could be the first test of new reforms to Australia's Privacy Act.

item.title: Free speech fears continue to roil US as Trump says unfair media coverage is 'illegal'
item.description: What began as a late-night joke has spiralled into a test of free speech in Trump’s America.

item.title: Healing land and spirit through Noongar knowledge and regenerative land management
item.description: In Western Australia's Wheatbelt, a region long shaped by industrial farming practices, a new model of regenerative agriculture is taking root. At Yaraguia farm, Ballardong Noongar man Oral McGuire is healing Country, reconnecting First Nations knowledge of caring for Country with modern land management to restore ecosystems and produce food that benefits both the land and the community.

item.title: 'Incredibly tragic event': Fourth death linked to 10-hour Optus triple-zero outage
item.description: South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas blasted the telco's slow and "bewildering" response, vowing it would be held to account for the outage that affected approximately 600 triple-zero calls.

item.title: 'Incredibly tragic event': Fourth death linked to 10-hour Optus triple-zero outage
item.description: South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas blasted the telco's slow and "bewildering" response, vowing it would be held to account for the outage that affected approximately 600 triple-zero calls.

item.title: I feel like privacy is dead: IVF data breach triggers interest in class action lawsuit
item.description: After years of trying to conceive, Isabel Lewis thought the hard part was over — until cybercriminals targeted her fertility clinic. The data breach at Genea Fertility included patient's medical histories, diagnoses and treatments, medications and prescriptions, as well as pathology and diagnostic test results. Now, hundreds of Australians have shown interest in a class action lawsuit over the breach, which could be the first test of new reforms to Australia's Privacy Act.

item.title: The 80th General Assembly of the UN is meeting in New York. How does it work - and why?
item.description: World leaders will gather in New York next week for the annual General Assembly. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has highlighted peace, climate, responsible innovation, gender equality, development financing and UN reform as central themes of the week. But the high-level week of the General Assembly also marks the 80th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations. We take a look at just what the UNGA is and what its powers are.

item.title: TikTok deal still unclear as Trump, Xi lower tensions in first call in months
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping have pledged to meet in South Korea next month after their first phone call in three months.

item.title: Jess Hull breaks Australian record and qualifies for 800m final at World Athletics Championships
item.description: The 28-year-old recorded a time of 1:57.15 and placed third in her semi-final heat in Tokyo on Friday night.

item.title: Why some Australian parents are giving their kids as much as $200k
item.description: Parents and grandparents are increasingly offering financial assistance to family members with 20 per cent saying they provided help in the last quarter.

item.title: SA Premier launches an examination of Optus' conduct | Midday News Bulletin 20 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Peter Malinauskas launches an examination of Optus' conduct after the deaths of two South Australians were linked to the telco's outage; Estonia seeks NATO help after Russian warplanes enter its airspace; and in sport, Canada ends New Zealand's eight-year reign as women's rugby world champions.

item.title: 'Unprecedentedly brazen': Estonia invokes Nato treaty after Russian jets violate airspace
item.description: Russia's defence ministry denied its jets violated Estonian airspace, saying they flew over neutral waters.

item.title: The 'quite simple' way this group of Australians could save lives
item.description: Australians receiving treatment for "urgent" and "critical" diseases are having to wait for people overseas to make life-saving donations.

item.title: Federal government inquiry into fatal Optus outage | Evening News Bulletin 20 August 2025
item.description: A full federal government inquiry into the deadly Optus outage... Estonia says Russia's reported violation of its airspace shows its time to get tough... and a big, late blow for the Canberra Raiders ahead of tonight's huge National Rugby League semi-final

item.title: A full federal government inquiry into the deadly Optus outage
'Not exactly glamorous': The 'disheartening' reality of dating in rural Australia
item.description: Rural Australians say dating in the country is a whole lot harder than in the city, with geographic isolation the least of their worries. Finding someone with the same values and lifestyle priorities is often the hardest challenge, which is why singles events in the sticks are having such a big impact.

item.title: The UN has reached a historic milestone. The world will be watching what it does next
item.description: This week's United Nations meeting will be a landmark occasion for multiple reasons.

item.title: Opinions divided on how to save our precious mountain ash forests
item.description: New research has found Australia's heat-stressed forests are rapidly thinning, and could even be producing carbon emissions. It comes as the government prepares to release its 2035 emissions targets and a climate risk report later this month. But local researchers, politicians and Traditional Owner land groups remain divided on how to protect the forest.

item.title: A fourth fatality confirmed in the Optus Triple-Zero outage | Morning News Bulletin 21 September 2025
item.description: A fourth fatality confirmed as authorities investigate the Optus triple-zero outage; Hamas issues a hostage farewell montage as Israel continues to pound Gaza City; and in sport, reigning premiers Brisbane Lions book their spot in the AFL finals.

item.title: John Santi lays his brother's remains to rest after finding out museum displayed specimens without consent
item.description: A coronial investigation launched in Tasmania in 2016 has found the University of Tasmania removed and kept human remains without consent or approval. The investigation raises broader questions about collections of human remains in other universities and museums in Australia, and what obligation these institutions have to identify their origin.

item.title: White House issues clarification after Trump hits H-1B visas with $150,000 fee
item.description: The announcement sparked concerns among employees across swaths of corporate America.

item.title: Here's the tea: Global shortage means steep prices for matcha lovers
item.description: Global matcha prices are surging due to poor weather in Japan, rising global demand, labour shortages, and steep US tariffs on imports from Japan and China. Now, the world’s love affair with matcha may be tested - at the checkout counter.

item.title: At least 60 Palestinians killed as Israel presses on with Gaza City assault
item.description: The Israeli military estimates it has demolished up to 20 Gaza City tower blocks over the past two weeks.

item.title: Republicans warn Australia of 'punitive measures' recognising Palestinian statehood
item.description: Anthony Albanese will recognise Palestinian statehood along with other world leaders at the UN General Assembly this week.

item.title: A cyber attack has hit some of Europe's busiest airports. Here's what you need to know
item.description: The cyber attack on check-in systems caused cancellations and long delays for thousands of passengers.

item.title: Albanese in New York for UN meeting | Midday News Bulletin 21 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese arrives in New York for a meeting of the UN General Assembly, Australia and allies are threatened with "punitive measures" over Palestinian. And in athletics, Australian Mackenzie Little has secured her second bronze medal on the international stage.

item.title: NATO jets fly over Poland | Evening News Bulletin 21 September 2025
item.description: In this bulletin, NATO jets fly over Poland in planned response to Russian incursion this month, Optus customers share their ordeal over being cut off from emergency services. And in the sport, Oscar Piastri still eyeing a formula one title, after crashing at the Azerbaijan Grand Prix.

item.title: 'Disgraceful': Optus launches investigation, reveals two more emergency call failures
item.description: Optus says alongside an investigation, it will launch a new compulsory escalation process following any customer reports of 000 failures.

item.title: 'Wait for it': Netanyahu warns Australia, other nations for recognising Palestinian state
item.description: Australia's recognition does not require ratification in the parliament or any United Nations vote to come into effect — it is now official government policy.

item.title: 'Remarkable': How Gaza protests unfolded in Australia and around the world
item.description: Australia is considered a "low protest country" but it has held some of the biggest pro-Palestinian protests in the world. Explore how Gaza protests have unfolded in our interactive map.

item.title: Some Australians are not confident about their retirement. Here's how much you need a year
item.description: Australians looking for work in their 40s and women, especially those divorced or single with children, are not feeling confident about retirement.

item.title: Australia officially recognises a Palestinian state at the UN | Morning News Bulletin 22 September 2025
item.description: Australia officially recognises a Palestinian state at the United Nations; Charlie Kirk memorial brings out the MAGA faithful; And in sport, Penrith crushes Canterbury-Bankstown to keep their premiership hopes alive.

item.title: Israeli drone strike kills five in southern Lebanon, including children
item.description: Reportedly among the dead were a family of US citizens.

item.title: What penalties could Optus face after its 'second significant and egregious failure'
item.description: The Australian Communications and Media Authority has announced its investigation into the Optus triple-zero outage, with the communications minister warning there will be consequences for the sector.

item.title: Murdoch family joins TikTok US ownership deal, says Trump
item.description: US President Donald Trump announced that media executive Lachlan Murdoch will be among business leaders involved in a proposed deal to keep TikTok operating in the United States under American ownership.

item.title: Australia's Jewish community reacts over Palestine recognition | Midday News Bulletin 22 September 2025
item.description: Mixed reaction from Australia's Jewish community to recognition of Palestine; Investigations into the fatal Optus outage now underway; And in sport, high jumper Nicola Olyslagers reflects on her gold medal.

item.title: Donald Trump praises right-wing activist Charlie Kirk as a 'martyr' at memorial event
item.description: Kirk's widow Erika delivered a more than 20-minute speech during which she forgave her husband's alleged killer.

item.title: More Israeli strikes hit Lebanon, Gaza
item.description: An Israeli drone strike on the Lebanese town of Bint Jbeil has killed five people, including three children, despite a US-brokered ceasefire with Hezbollah. The tragedy comes as Gaza endures another wave of bombardments, with dozens killed in the past day alone.

item.title: SBS News in Easy English 22 September 2025
item.description: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: Prosecutors to consider charges as police end investigation into Kumanjayi White's death
item.description: A mandatory coronial investigation into the death in custody of Kumanjayi White remains ongoing.
